awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CCRI: Planning-C: An Infrastructure and Dataset for Research in Android Testing & Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Given the importance of mobile applications (apps), researchers have dedicated considerable effort toward understanding, supporting, and automating mobile app development tasks. However, researchers looking to contribute to this area of work face several challenges related to building and maintaining tooling that can keep pace with the rapid evolution of mobile platforms (e.g., new Android updates) and the continuous process of mining apps and app-related data. This project aims to carry out planning activities that will lead to the construction of a new shared community infrastructure for conducting mobile app development research. This infrastructure, called MODAL, will support work across the disciplines of software engineering (SE), computer security, and human-computer interaction (HCI) by offering various configurable components supporting key steps of the research process.

This project will (1) conduct a preliminary survey of the SE, computer security, and HCI communities to understand the mobile app research needs of these communities, (2) conduct interviews to understand the barriers researchers face and how a specific community infrastructure can mitigate these barriers, (3) host workshops to facilitate the exchange of best practices used for mining data and building analysis tools to guide the development of the infrastructure, (4) conduct a working group to explore the design of the infrastructure with existing researchers, researchers new to the topic, and educators of the topic, and (5) conduct a summative survey to assess the proposed infrastructure’s ability to support mobile app research. 

The improved tools and techniques proposed by this project will better support app developers, enabling them to write higher quality applications, potentially impacting billions of app users. This project will also explore the potential for using the envisioned infrastructure to teach students how to effectively write mobile app software. Finally, as part of the proposed planning activities, barriers and challenges related to research on mobile app development will be uncovered that will inform new types of classroom pedagogy and new tools that will benefit novice researchers.

The long-term goal of this project is the creation of a sustainable open-source community centered around the proposed research infrastructure. The community will be fostered by the development of clear contribution guidelines, proper attribution of researcher contributions, and the distribution of researcher contributions to the larger academic community. During the planning period, we will maintain a website that contains details related to the survey, workshop, working group, and summative report outlining the proposed design of the research infrastructure. The website can be found at the following link: www.sagelab.io/modal

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As smartphones have become essential tools in our daily lives—handling everything from banking to healthcare—ensuring the quality and security of mobile apps is more important than ever. However, researchers who aim to improve mobile apps face steep challenges. The fast-changing Android ecosystem, the unique touch-based interface of apps, and the lack of up-to-date tools and datasets make it difficult to conduct effective, reproducible research.

Our project, supported by the National Science Foundation, set out to lower these barriers. We brought together a diverse group of researchers and industry professionals through surveys and workshops to define what the research community truly needs. The feedback we gathered helped shape our proposed infrastructure, called MODAL (MObile app Data collection and AnaLysis).

The planning phase of this project revealed strong demand for a shared platform that can keep up with the rapid pace of Android app development and provide standardized tools and data. In our survey of 58 researchers across 7 countries, over 88% said they would be extremely likely to use such an infrastructure. To further involve the community, we hosted two international workshops—one at ICST 2024 and one at FSE 2024—each attended by more than 20 academic and industry participants. These workshops underscored the need for standardized benchmarks, reproducible environments, and shared datasets to move the field forward.

Our planned MODAL platform is designed to be exactly that: a flexible, community-driven infrastructure that continuously gathers, analyzes, and shares data from Android apps. It will include:

  • A Hybrid Analysis Framework to help researchers conduct both dynamic (app behavior during execution) and static (app source code) analyses with reusable tools.

  • A Dataset Collection System that automatically updates itself with new app versions and usage data, keeping research current and relevant.

  • Benchmarks for AI Techniques, enabling more robust testing and development of machine learning models used in app analysis and testing.

MODAL also supports educational goals. By reducing the time and effort needed to collect and prepare data, students and early-career researchers can more easily focus on designing experiments, interpreting results, and exploring new ideas. We plan to integrate MODAL into courses and tutorials and to engage with educators to further its reach.

From bug detection to privacy analysis to UI testing, MODAL opens new doors across disciplines—including software engineering, human-computer interaction, cybersecurity, and AI. It will empower researchers to ask new questions and uncover insights that were previously out of reach due to technical or logistical limitations.

By establishing a sustainable and collaborative research infrastructure, our work aims to catalyze innovation in the mobile software space. The planning activities we conducted confirm a shared community vision: mobile research should be easier, more inclusive, and more impactful. MODAL is a major step in that direction.
